author: Legobuilderguy
title: Very Nice
review:
Got this set last night at a local Wal-Mart. They were bringing out the 2010 sets due to having NO Lego on the shelves. This is a very nice set indeed. It appears to be an update of the last outing of the land speeder set so for those, like me, who missed it the last time, this was great. The build on this is pretty easy but there are a couple of points in the instructions which were rather vague about where something went but other than that not bad. The color scheme in this set is very nice as well. Looks rather like a beat up used speeder should. Price was a bit high, 24.99 USD so that is a bit much I think. However, what made it worth it to me was that I now have a C3PO mini fig. 

Pros: 
Looks good once built.
Young Luke.
Old Obi-Wan Kenobi.
C3PO 
Grey headed R2-D2.
Nice storm trooper.

Cons:
Price per piece is a bit steep.
No place for R2 to sit.

What it comes down to is that you get 5 mini figs and a somewhat classical set. I think this is the third or fourth outing for this set so it's not really something we haven't seen before, but it is nice that we are able to get this if we missed it before. Looking at the current line up of Star Wars sets, we are going to be seeing some more re-releases this year which is both good and bad. So far with this one it is worth it as it allowed me to not only get a nice set I didn't have before but also the one mini figure I was missing. Great buy all in all.

author: CTUDarkZero
title: Good Ol' Landspeeder
review:
I was looking in the lego shelfs at a local wal-mart when I came across this lego set. Seeing that it was the only one left on the shelfs, I bought it. And I gotta say, this is a fine set, although a bit pricey. It's a pretty decent set, as you get a new version of the landspeeder, and it is the best one to date. Also, you get five great minifigs, and it really does feel like it's recreating a classical scene from Episode IV. It's a great set, real fun to build, and definetily worth having in a lego star wars collection. 

Pros:
Luke Skywalker (long hair version)
Ben Kenobi
R2-D2 (new colored head)
C-3PO (Already had one, but like the new color)
Stormtrooper
New version of speeder
Not one, but two lightsabers.

Cons:
A little bit overpriced


Aside from that one little con, this is a set your going to want to get.

author: PluffTed
title: Very Nice Set
review:
I bought this set today at my local Walmart in San Diego, CA and was impressed by it.  The 6 minifigs I received with it were really cool!  All of the minifigs were new, but you could argue the C-3PO isn't.  I really loved the Luke and Obi-Wan figs, but I also liked the other ones too!  I bought this set for $25, but ended up being about $28 with taxes which was kind of a rip-off.  

Pros:

-Fun, easy build!
-Awesome minifigs!
-Very, very movie accurate!
-Colorful and spread-
around pieces!

Cons:

-Expensive set!
-Removable trunk dosen't 
fit Luke's and Obi-Wan's 
lightsabers!
-Should have included another
Sandtrooper instead of a Sentry Droid!

author: ChrisBricks1138
title: This is the set you're looking for!
review:
I just bought this set from my local Toys-R-Us, and I have to say, for the price I paid for it, the set is extremely worth it!

PROS: 

Luke and Ben Kenobi have new face designs
Sandtrooper with a black pauldron which looks awesome
Incredible Lanspeeder vehicle, a vast improvement on previous models
Removable back part to store Luke and Obi-Wan's lightsabers
R2-D2 with new head design from Battle of Endor and Tantive IV
Sentry droid is a nice addition

CONS:

Wires are a little difficult to put in
A weeny bit pricey perhaps?

Overall, a great set, with lots of rare minifigs and a brilliant Lanspeeder. I highly recommend this set to anyone who is an original trilogy fan, or a serious collector of LEGO Star Wars of any kind!

author: primetime
title: First set I feel REALLY ripped off with...
review:
I would have put a review on LEGO.com but somehow I don't think they'd entertain a negative review such as this.

"Amazing" and "Value for money" say the reviews on LEGO.com for this Landspeeder set. I'd have to disagree.

My wife bought me this from a local toy shop at £24.99 and I feel that this is the biggest LEGO Star Wars rip-off in a long time. The mini-figures are a must-have for collectors and maybe that is why they are included, to somehow justify this enormous price tag.

If you compare the differences with this set to the Hoth Battle Packs (8084 and 8083) then the scandalous asking price is plain to see. You get four decent mini-figures in each of those plus the extra mini vehicle for £9.99. With this set you get five fairly good mini-figures plus a slightly bigger vehicle (the Landspeeder) for another 14.98 extra.

If it had been me picking it up in the shop then I probably would have left it. Now the two Hoth Battle Packs are a different story...

author: Lego_Minifig_Man
title: "These aren't the droids your looking for."-Ben Kenobi, A New Hope
review:
I'm trying a new way of organizing my reviews. Let me know if you like this way better than the my others. Okay! 

This is a great set, and it is so  much better than the previous two landspeeder sets! (One being incuded in Mos Eisley) 

Minifigures (And Droids):
Pros- The sandtrooper's backpack-thing has two (non-shiny) lightsaber hilts (handles). The sandtroopers fabric-thing is really cool! The "New Hope" Luke has a new chest piece.

Cons- The sandtrooper's face is black. Luke's hair makes him look like a girl. (Luckily, I had a blonde short hair peice from a older set) R2-D2's top part is a different color than the rest of him. Ben has no cape. (I was hoping for a brown one with a hood) The sentry droid dosen't really look like it's hovering.

Landspeeder:
Pros- Looks incredible and accurate! Good colors, don't see too many of those reds around!

Cons- There's no place for Artoo to sit. The windsheild should go higher up. (They'd get a lot of sand in the face if that was in the movie) I don't like how the, uh, thruster-rocket things are different. They should have the different one on the top instead.

Trunk of landspeeder:
Pros- You can store things in there... You can fit a minifig with short legs in there (Not included).

Cons- The lightsabers can't fit in there while their blades are attached.

Other:
Pros- The lightsaber hilts (handles) are shiny-silver. The lightsaber blades are just cool alone.

Cons- The set was a bit too pricy. I would've preffered it, well, free, but I think it should have been $29.99, instead of $34.83

Conslusion:
If you have to buy only one set from A New Hope, it should be this one. Sure it has it's ups and downs, but overall it's really cool.

author: Duq
title: Great set but overpriced
review:
I bought this set for €29,99 in the local toy shop. I love the old Star Wars movies and this is one of the most recognisable vehicles from the first movie.

The Landspeeder has been done before. 7110 was one of the first batch of Star Wars sets back in 1999. It's still cute but looks a bit clunky now.
The second version came in 2004 in 4501, the Mos Eisley Cantina set. It's longer and wider than the first set and the main colour has gone from tan to sand red. The left hand side motor has a different colour to mimic the damage you see in the film. The Stormtrooper and the 'floating' Sentry droid tie this set to the scene where Luke and Obi Wan enter Mos Eisley. "These are not the droids you're looking for..."

This time around the design hasn't changed as much; the front is nearly identical to the speeder from 4501. The colour has gone back to tan, the windscreen is now a curvy one (from the SpeedRacer sets) and the engines are different again. The left hand side now has a different design as well as colour.

The set comes with 5 minifigs (one of them C3PO!) and a Sentry droid. The trooper looks cool with his shoulder pad but I'm not sold on Luke with his girly hair. This is also the first Landspeeder set with flesh minifig heads.

I really like the speeder. While sand-red is probably more true to the original the colours here work really well. The curved windscreen is a big improvement and I also really like the redesigned engines. It's also great to get R2D2 and C-3PO together.
The only big problem, as has been said in other reviews, is the price. At €29,99 for 163 pieces it is well overpriced.

If you don't have a Landspeeder yet this set is a must-have. Otherwise it's one for the die-hard collectors.

author: superdave
title: Great Moves
review:
Parts: 5/5. The parts selection is much better than I anticipated. Flex tube, dark red, cheese slopes and "grilled cheese" are all present, along with the slick "Speed Racer" windshield.

Minifigs: 5/5. Five figures (including the hard-to-find C-3PO) for $25 isn't a bad deal, and the figures themselves are quite good (especially the sandtrooper with backpack)!

Build: 4/5. The build is smooth and straightforward but features a couple of really great "moves," including a good studs-down connection on the rear engine.

Playability: 4/5. Basically, it's just a "car in space." However, the IM4-099 droid and sandtrooper give you enough to reenact the "not the droids you're looking for" scene flawlessly.

Price: 3/5. The price is high but it's a licensed exclusive with five figs; I wouldn't really expect it to be much less (although $20 would be a great price). If you can get it on sale that would be very cool.

Overall: 4/5. It's a solid set at a solid price and lots of fun.

author: joelmama29
title: THIRD TIME IS A CHARM! SO THEY SAY
review:
Well another rererelease from Lego! This is the third Land Speeder released from lego since 1999. I am puzzled why Lego would do this again but of course it is Lego and they make us all wonder at times. The set is self is nice, some of the pros that stick is you get 5 mini figs 6 if you count the Sentry Droid. I like the older Luke version with printed legs, but this new one is great version as well. I like the R2-D2 with the grey dome. This is a great set if you are into mini figs and you want to pick up an original trilogy Luke and Obi. 

The Storm Trooper is the highlight of the set I love the how the recreated the backpack from the movie and the black shoulder pad showing the StormTroopers rank. This very similar to the Mos Eisley set. This is a great mini fig to add to the Mos Eisley set or vice versa. 

This is great set to pick up if you were not able to get any of the earlier versions of Luke's LandSpeeder. The speeder itself if very similar to the other sets, they all have a secret comparment in the back to store the lightsabers. Also the the build is similar. I do like the windshiel on this new set more movie accurate and you can fit all the droids on the set which is cool as well. I also like the third engine if you notice it is different then the other two because in the movie the landspeeder has an engine with exposed wires. 

The only real Con on this set is the price point. This is a pricey set for its size and number of pieces. Who ever reads this review please note this set is 25.00 bucks at your local Wal-Mart it is more at Toys R Us try 30-33 bucks. 

I would have given this set a 5 but again I love the Mos Eisley set because of the mounted Storm Trooper on the DewBack Lizard and you get Greedo! But again for new collectors a great set to start with. 

Pros:
- 6 Mini Figs 
- Awesome Storm Trooper 
- The newly redisgned R2-D2 

Cons 
- Price to expensive for this size of set! 
- Another LandSpeeder

author: wouterdb
title: 5 minifigs !
review:
Nice set, compared to the 1999 set more than an improvement !

Pro:
- a lot of minifigs
- pearl gold 3CPO
- new R2D2
- lightsaber departement

Con:
- too expensive (I think Lego has to pay a lot to Lucas)
- the red and brown colors don't match very well

author: Commander_Bly
title: Here comes the Landspeeder!
review:
Welcome to my review of Luke's Landspeeder!

This is a very good set, with some nice pieces, but one thing I am terribly disappointed with, is that it is WAY overpriced! I mean, 163 pieces for $25? Come on LEGO, wake up!

Here are my Pros and Cons:

PROs:

  • Nice figures
  • Good pieces

CONs:

  • Too expensive!
  • Didn't take me long to build it

 

I'd say this is a great set for the beginner or intermediate builder if you are buying it for the set and figs, but if you are buying this for the pieces, it is not worth it. ;)

~Flare/Commander_Bly

author: shieldsy
title: drive to survive
review:
This is a great set.The set comes with five mini figs excluding the sentry droid.The mini figs are luke skywalker,old ben kenobi,stormtrooper(tatoine) with a pauldren and a breathing pack,c-3po and our old pal r2d2.When I opened the box I cried with relief that there was no stickers.On the set there is damage on the right engine.At the back engine when you lift it up it reveals a lightsaber compartment.

                              pros:

                              lightsaber compartment

                              landspeeder

                              cons:

                              lukes girly hair

Overall I would rate this set 10/10.Hope this helped.

author: Mageamooney
title: Luke's awesome Landspeeder!
review:
Luke's Landspeeder is a great set - it fits nicely into your hand and has some great, rare minifigs.

 

Pros:

  • Nice new, rare minifigs
  • Fits nicely in your hand
  • Good for moving over smooth surfaces with the bricks underneath

Cons:

  • A bit overpriced for just over 150 pieces

Summary:

Overall, the Landspeeder is a great small set, and I enjoyed building it, as it can fit into your routine - it doesn't take too long to build (5 mins if a fast builder - 15 mins if quite a slow builder). Though a little overpriced, it's a great set, and would recommend it to any Lego Star Wars fan.

  •

author: EtudeTheBadger
title: 'These aren't the droids you're (oh, you know how the rest goes)
review:
Some time back (a decade and a bit, actually) I bought the original LEGO Landspeeder from my local Woolworths. Times have changed, people- Woolworth's ain't around no more, and LEGO has since upped the game and advanced.

As an owner of the original 1999 model, I have to say that this model is one heck of an improvement. A lot of LEGO's reimaginings don't do the original models justice or are cheap-looking rehashes. However, this Landspeeder stands tall as a true step forward.

While building the 'speeder, I loved how small details are woven into the model, such as the structure of the dashboard and the gentle curve of the windshield. The colours, which started out as some pretty basic red, tan and a little splish of grey, have been complimented by a superb adding of that dark red we've all come to adore. The engine nacelles are smartly made with proper grey engine parts and one is even rendered in a sort of 'pared-down' state like in A New Hope. Carrying on, and the set features some super minifigs. Starring in this production are Luke Skywalker, good old Obi-wan Kenobi, a really golden C-3PO, R2-D2 and a stormtrooper with his security droid. That's a pretty great lineup, hey? Now you can reenact that famous scene (you know the one I'm talking about) without having to buy several sets for the figures! But try not to get blinded by reflected light from C-3PO's new sheen.

Whoops! Now onto the cons... and there are some. First off, the price. Ahem. 25 big ones for a set that, a couple of years ago, would have been a tenner? Whoa there! Secondly, there's a useless storage compartment in the back of the speeder. What in this set can it store? The Imperial's blaster? Yeah, right. Maybe you could store the lightsabers - in 'off' mode, i.e. remove the blades - in there, but that makes little sense. Lastly, Luke's hair. It's just not movie realistic. If Mark Hamill had've sported this barnet in A New Hope, he would have looked like He-Man. Go back to the round hair, LEGO!

All in all, it's a great set and a must for hardcore SW fans. The price is a point of personal taste, but that shouldn't be a problem for the more dedicated among us...


-maaboo35!

author: THX_1138
title: A must have for OT fans!
review:
This is one of three OT sets in winter 2010, and is the best one. 

Pros:

  • Excellent minifigs: Exclusive sandtrooper with black pauldron, Tatooine Luke with a new face, rare old Ben, and semi-rare C-3PO. It's also got the far more common R2-D2.
  • The speeder is well made and accurate.
  • The engines are much better than on previous versions.
  • The left engine on the speeder is made so that it resembles the one on the actual speeder that was missing a cover.
Cons:

  • The Imperial droid isn't very good. Probably an afterthought.
  • The speeder is a bit too stud-y, and could have used some plates.
This is an excellent set, and should definitely be bought, especially if you missed the old Mos Eisely Cantina version. I've heard it's been hard to find in Wal-Marts (I never found it, but my Wal-Marts usually aren't too good anyway), and had to buy it form S@H. It was on backorder then, but it isn't now, so I'd get it before it's too late.

author: KLOKRIECHER
title: "These are not the droids you've been looking for..."
review:
The Luke's Landspeeder set (8092) is a LEGO Star Wars set which came out in 2011. It comes with 6 minifigures. This set doesn't include decals.

[img]http://www.klokriecher.de/gallery_pics/l/8092-1.jpg[/img]

Minifigure:

  • Luke Skywalker: Luke Skywalker comes with his basic Tatooine outfit and printed legs. He has long hair. I think he looks like a girl with this hair. He has a blue lightsaber and a chrome handle for the lightsaber. Luke has bigger eyes if you compare him to the Luke Skywalker from the older Landspeeder set and the one which came out in the Visual Dictionary Book.
  • Obi-Wan Kenobi (Ben Kenobi): Obi-Wan looks much different from the version we got in 2000. He has better details on his face and he has big eyes. He comes with a blue lightsaber aswell and he also has the basic Jedi outfit. The only problem is that this figure doesn't come with a cape and a hood.
  • C-3PO: C-3PO has a better detail on his color which looks more golden now. He has a printing on the back.
  • R2-D2: R2 has a new printing on the top. But he looks very basic if you compair him to the other R2-D2 minifigs.
  • Sandtrooper: The Sandtrooper comes with a basic Stormtrooper armor and a printing on his back. He comes with a little cape and a backpack. He has a black head underneath his helmet.
  • Sentry Droid: The Sentry Droid has just some bricks. He has some clear bricks on the bottom which makes the stand and the red clear stund on the front and the lever on the back.

Landspeeder:

  • The Landspeeder is very cool. It has a trunk there you can store the lightsabers or the extra pieces you get. On the back is a small engine. On the top and on the right and left side is a bigger one. One engine looks damaged due to the sandpeople. It has a windscreen which LEGO used on the Speed Racers sets which was a subtheme of the LEGO Racers theme back in 2008. Even the 'walls' on the front look a bit damaged. There you can see some cables. Underneath the speeder are some dish plates for easy playability. You also get two sets for the minifigs and a steering-wheel.

Positive:

  • Minifigures
  • Bigger then the first Landspeeder
  • Play features
  • Great pieces which you can youse for brickfilms or MOCs.
  • No Stickers

Negative:

  • It's a little bit overpriced
  • Stickers
  • You have to take the lightsaber blades of the handles if you want to put it in the trunk


All in all it's a great set to get and I would highly recommend you to get this model. You can find this set on LEGO Shop@Home, Toys-R-US, eBay, BrickLink and Amazon for sure.

When I got my galery uploaded you may check out my own website to see the pictures of this model. At the moment I can't show you the full galery because my server is too small and I'm trying to get a bigger one. Here is the link where you can check out this galery: http://www.klokriecher.de

Videos I made of this set:

Stopmotion: http://www.youtube.com/user/KLOKRIECHER?feature=mhum#p/search/0/Pnljx-Tabyo
Review: http://www.youtube.com/user/KLOKRIECHER?feature=mhum#p/search/1/IG0JktvTIok

author: legoDad42
title: Nice Landspeeder!
review:
Luke's Landspeeder is a nice small/mid size set that is a good build and great playability for kid's or the AFoL recreating the famous Jedi-Mind Trick on the Stormtroopers in Mos Eisley plus excellent mini-figs!

 

PRO's...

  • Overall sleek, well designed speeder. Has the right feel, proportion and shape from the movie.
  • Nice color scheme with tan and dark red accents throughout.
  • Left engine detail 'exposed' like the one in the movie.
  • Hidden trunk/compartment in rear. Lift the back engine to reveal a space for the lightsabers, etc.
  • Brick built Sentry Droid has a nice simple/effective look and is attached to 2 clear cylinder pieces on a clear base simulating it's floating.

 

Mini-figs are just excellent. Luke with new 'wig' and brush-metal lightsaber handle. Obi-Wan as well has a brush metal lightsaber handle. Stormtrooper with laser pistol has a neat backpack with grey lightsaber handles as containters (use the extra black stud on top of one of the saber handles and the extra antennae from the Sentry Droid on the other handle to give it a better look and disquise the saber handles better) and black shoulder paltron. Great looking C-3PO and R2-D2 figures. Note on the box cover photo, they list the Sentry Droid with the other mini-figs but it's not a mini-fig but neat brick built droid.

 

CON's...

  • Luke's hair seems a bit too long. Kinda' like the one from the Star Wars DK book exclusive.
  • For some strange reason, Obi-Wan doesn't have a hood nor cape/cloak.
  • Rear compartment too small for lightsabers. Need to take apart saber and handle to fit them properly.
  • Bland looking cockpit.
  • Sentry Droid NOT a mini-fig. A true min-fig must have a unique sculpt or print pattern.
  • Another Stormtrooper mini-fig with orange shoulder paltron needed here.

Overall I recommend this set for the young Lego builder. Only $5.00 too high but it has neat figures and a wonderfully designed Luke's Landspeeder. Slight mod's here and there on the Landspeeders cockpit and perhaps add more room in the rear compartment can improve the kit but regardless, this a must get for any Star Wars fan and good selection of 5 min-figs! Get one now!

author: power_miner2020
title: A great set for 2010
review: This is a great set for people that don't have a sandtrooper.Now are the things I like about this set!First ever sandtrooper in 2010.You can remember the landspeeder from episode IV:a new hope.A cargo bay in the landspeeder.And the first ever 2010 sentry droid.

author: vynsane
title: Ever since the XP-38 came out, they just aren't in demand.
review:
The Star Wars universe's answer to a teenager's first hand-me-down clunker of a car, the X-34 Landspeeder fully invokes those old feelings (that I know all too well) of oil leaks, fuse box issues and coolant system failures with its one exposed engine (either because of necessary body-work in progress or chronic engine problems), uncovered power circuits for quick access and dingy coat of paint. The fact that Luke got enough money to buy passage off Tatooine by selling this thing is a miracle... or just a testament to how desperate Han was.

Figures

This set comes with 5 minifigures in total, though somehow the brick-built 'Sentry Droid' counts(?). The true minifigures we get, however, are AWESOME.
  • Luke Skywalker - While the hair might be a bit longer than it should be, the sandy blond color is spot-on. The printing on the torso as well as the legs is a perfect representation of Luke's outfit from 'A New Hope'
  • Ben Kenobi - Ben's printed torso is a fine interpretation of his tan tunic, but the absence of his brown Jedi robe/hood is disappointing.
  • C-3P0 - 3P0's specially-molded head is perfect, and the printing on the torso spot-on.
  • R2-D2 - Though a bit too large in relation to the other figures R2 is represented in superb fashion.
  • Imperial Sandtrooper - Standard Stormtrooper, with the addition of a black cloth shoulder pauldron and... some sort of backpack.
  • Sentry Droid - Meh. Looks like a tablescrap made from the set's spare parts. I wish they had included a second trooper instead of a rather lackluster 'droid'. It would probably have pushed the value rating up a brick.

Accessories

  • Lightsaber (x2) - Ben and Luke each get their own Lightsaber, complete with silver hilt and transparent light blue 4L bar.
  • Standard Blaster Rifle, backpack, and shoulder pauldron - For the Sandtrooper

Build

The build is interesting, with some rather clever SNOT techniques, especially with the engines. Being the third version of this vehicle, it's an improvement on both - more so from the first one (7110 - Landspeeder), with only apparently minor tweaks from the second (4501 - Mos Eisley Cantina). If you only have the first version, I would 'trade it in'. If you have the second version I might just suggest waiting to 'paying it off'. It would be cool to modify the build with some 'caster' type hidden wheels to both lift the speeder off the ground a bit and provide rolling action.

Authenticity

The colors seem off - almost like it's opposite from what it should be, tan where it should be dark red and vice-versa. As it stands, it's a fair representation of the source material, but not a direct translation. There are improvements that can be made if one were so inclined.

Parts

This set includes some relatively rare parts, like two light blue-gray tubes (21L) and dark red tiles and cheese slopes, but other than that it's relatively standard fare. The use of one mis-matched engine (to represent the engine with the panels removed) is an inspiration.

Conclusion

I bought this for full price because of the relative rarity - I'd only seen it the once in a retail establishment, and LEGO Shop@Home keeps pushing the backorder date further into the future. It's not a great value for the piece count, and if you have impulse control you may eventually find it on sale. That said, I didn't have the willpower this time.

author: tom_skywalker
title: So cool
review:
I win this set monday, and is so cool.

 

Minifigures: 9/10

Pros: Ben, Luke, R2, C3PO, Strooper ans Sentry Droid, if you got Tusken Raiders u can reneact de schene of the movie

Cons: the sentry Droid is simple, not many deatailed

 

The set: 10/10

Place to the droids sit

 

Cons:

Final score: 9/10

author: Skyboss
title: This version is one that Lego got right
review:
This is one of three Luke Skywalker speeders that Lego has made and they got it right this time!! I got this set at Walmart for about $25 if you don't count Illinois state tax. Anyway, onto the review!
The parts: Lego included some rare parts including the long tubes, jet turbines and rare dark red/maroon pieces.
The minifigures: Ben Kenobi has a different face than other renditions in other sets, Luke Skywalker has printed legs and longer hair than normal. C-3P0 is much more gold than other versions.
The build: This set is a quick build and is rather easy and straight foward. The set includes a  storage area for the lightsabers.
Overall: this set is recommended to beginners and those who have at least $30 us around with them.

author: Firox_5000
title: This the landspeeder we are looking for
review:
This is one of the most iconic sets lego has ever produced in the Star wars theme.

 

The set includes five wonerful mini figures Luke skywalker,Old obi one, c-3 p-0 , R-2 D-2 and a storm trooper. the also includes two wonderful new metalic light sabers as well as a spy droid. 

 

The Landspeeder is really nice and looks much better than past reincarnations. The colour and design is really nice and is sized well too. The only con is the lightsabers cant fit in the compartment on the speeder. Apart from that there are no other complaints except for only one thing.

 

The price! , For £25 the set is way too much and it is very small for it's size and it's even too much at £20 as well.

 

I recomend this set for the great figures and prouduct but I suggest you buy it for no more than £20.

author: Huge_Nerd
title: cool set, but overpriced
review:
pros:

  • great minifigs
  • iconic vehicle
  • good fun re-enacting scenes from A New Hope.
  • fun build for a smaller set

 

cons

  • really only the price, but the minifigs and uniquely colored pieces help justify it.

author: Doctor_Leg_O_Brick
title: these are the legos where looking for...
review:
To me, this is the best landspeeder out of the 1999 and 2004 sets. But enough of that, and on to the review.
 
THE BUILD
Great, i mean great. Fairly easy build, but young children may have problems with the pipes at the front.
 
THE PARTS
The engine parts are amazing, great idea having one different to the others. Theirs the odd uniqe piece, maybe two. Great MOC possibiltly here.
 
THE PLAYABILITY
Good if you like star wars 4, even if you have some other sets with jabba the hutt in. May i also note that if you remove the front 3 slates that their is a 1 stud gap, two on each side of the landspeeder. If you think, "why a gap on each side?" Well, this solves a problem that every ones saying. Thats where you put the the lightsabres, one on each side!! Simple!!
 
THE MONEY
Well, £25 is good for what you get. 5 (6 if you include the droid) minifigures comes with it, but it depends what you think.
 
THE MINIFIGURES
You get a sand trooper with a blaster(SE-14 blaster pistol), black sholder cape and a backpack, luke in farm outfit and  obi-wan or "ben" kenobi with lightsabres, C3P0, R2 D2 and sentry droid.
 
THE OVERALL RATING
I would give it a five bricks out of five because its just a great set.

author: ck614
title: A nice set which comes with quite rare minifigs.
review:
Intro

I have got this set and it is really really cool, I think it is too much money I recommend that it should be at least £17.99. I like the interior such as the steering wheel the seats and well mostly everything.

 

Review

Build the vehicle that Luke skywalker Obi-wan-kenobi drive into the Tatooine spaceport of Mos Eisley. Recreate the epic moment when Obi-wan-kenobi first uses the force on the imperial Sandtroopers by uttering "These are not the droids you're looking for." The set includes Obi-wan-kenobi, Luke Skywalker, R2-D2, C-3po and Sandtrooper guard minifigures.

The item #8092

Ages 7-12

Peices 163

Price £24.99 and $24.99

author: Stromeon
title: A great minifig starter
review:
This is a great little set to give you a start on some important minifigs.

Pros

  • Includes 4 key minifigs in the story - Luke, Obi-Wan, C-3PO, and R2-D2.
  • The Sandtrooper looks quite cool with his pauldron and jetpack - slightly different from ordinary stormtroopers
  • A sneaky little place to put lightsabers and other spare bits that come with the set
  • Some nice crimson coloured pieces to use elsewhere if or when dismantled

Cons

  • Not really many cons here... except that R2-D2 looks a bit out of proportion, he ends up being about twice the width of C-3PO

This is a perfect thing to get you started on a LEGO Star Wars collection, if you combine it with some of the battle packs, and the Landspeeder itself is quite versatile as either a transport or a quick getaway vehicle.

author: IndyAJD
title: This is the set your looking for...
review:
If your a Star Wars fan, this is definitely the set your looking for.  The speeder is good, the minifigs GREAT!  This is a great set (have you picked up on that yet?)!  It comes from one of the most iconic Star Wars scenes ever, and includes all of the necessary items to act it out. At $25.00 (USD) its a little overpriced, but the minifigs justify that.

Pros

  • Includes all of the minifigs necessary to accurately recreate the scene (for once).
  • Storage compartment in the back of the speeder.
  • I love the security droid!

Cons

  • A bit pricey

Overall, I would definitely recommend this set.  In other words, this is the set your looking for!

author: CapnRex101
title: 8092 - Luke's Landspeeder
review:
This is quite a good set, but not quite perfect. As many people have commented, the price for this set (£24.99) is too expensive, although what you do get is very nice, there is just not enough to justify the cost. 

Box/Instructions

The box art for this set includes a shot of the arrival of the group in Mos Eisley, with the Sandtrooper included in the set marching towards the speeder to be told the famous line "these are not the droids you're looking for." The background is simply a junk pile found in the space port sitting on the desert sands.

The instructions are as always faultless and easy to follow.

Parts

The parts for this set are not bad at all, many of the pieces are in dark red or tan which are both desirable colours, you also get some nice engine pieces which are not particularly rare but still useful. 

Minifigures

The Minifigures for this set are all you need to recreate this scene in Lego, occasionally Lego will make a set but not put enough figures in. That is certainly not the case here. These figures could be very useful if you wished to play out many of the scenes from A New Hope, including many key characters. The details are very good on many of the figures, such as Luke's shorts and belt, and Ben's lovely Jedi robe printing on his torso. I like the Sandtrooper with his black shoulder cape and backpack, although I think it would have looked better with the older orange capes like the old Sandtrooper from the Mos Eisley Cantina (4501) set. The sentry droid is of little use but a decent addition to the set nevertheless.

The build

The build is very short and easy, it took me about ten minutes and had no really interesting features to it, however I do like the use of the light grey piping around the front of the model.

The completed model

The look of the model is very accurate to the Landspeeder from the film, right down to the damaged engine on the left of the model. There are two seats in the cockpit of the speeder and a black steering wheel. The bodywork is well detailed for such a small set and I like the inclusion of a small storage compartment at the rear of the vehicle which does just about fit both lightsabers if you separate the hilts from the blades.

Summary

Overall I feel this set is perfect, but for one thing, the price is too high. Perhaps for about £15 this set would be more reasonable, but the price is still affordable, so I would recommend this.


Overall - 7/10

author: HanSolo_Jedi_lego_sik
title: such awsome minifgs
review:
I loved this set the good minifigs were what made me want to get it although it is a little bit expensive at £25 :/

Pros

Obi wan
Luke (awsome suit)
c3p0 and r2 d2
sandtroopers shoulder cape
brilliant speeder design
2 lightsabers

Cons


boots a little bit small
too expensive
sentry droid is a bit wierd
obi wan didnt have a cape :( (i was relly disappointed about it)

I would recomend this set mostly becaus eof the minifigs though

author: brickboyg
title: Fragile Figures, but overall a good set.
review:
Figures:

Luke Skywalker: Great torso and legs. Also has a different face to most previous Luke Skywalker figures. Great Figure.

C3PO: A golden beauty. Magnificent

R2D2: Nice cannon shaped body. Lots of printed buttons, levers etc on body. Silver head is also great.

Obi-Wan Kenobi: Great cape torso. Hair is nothing special, and for me a bit disappointing.

Sandtrooper: Nothing special. Also backpack is very fragile and delicate.

Sentry Droid: Reasonably good, but again fragile and delicate.

Pros:

1. Side and top engines are great.

2. Windows are cool, probably the best sort you can get, much better than the old and standard ones.

3. Cables/wires are good, but not at all perfect. Plus if you want a broken engine, take a wire out the sockets and it's sticking out.

Cons:

1. Cannot fit R2D2 in the landspeeder. For me this is a huge flaw.

2. Sandtrooper and Sentry droid are as i mentioned earlier, delicate.

3. The Sentry droid can obviously not fly, but for me the clear bricks are not very good (if they're trying to make the clear bricks hard to see.)

author: A_Brickset_user
title: A good set for Star Wars beginners...
review:
A good set for Star Wars beginners.

Why?

Let me show you:

Pros

  • It has six minifigures,Luke,Ben Kenobi(Obi-Wan),R2-D2,C-3PO,Sentry Droid and a SandTrooper!
  • It's good for starters,offering two Jedi,and the most iconic Star Wars characters : C-3PO and R2-D2!
  • It has a playability rate of 10,on a scale from 1 to 5!

Cons

  • The SandTrooper's head is black :(
  • Obi-Wan dosen't have a cape :(
  • Luke has a girlish hair :(

In conclusion this set is 9.6/10.A good set for starters!

author: comandercody654
title: A great re-make of a classic set :>
review:
O_O was my reaction when i saw this set. Old memories came back to me about the old landspeeder set.I just had to buy it! Having owned the 1999 version I wanted to see how LEGO remade this.I quicky bought it and raced home and boy I wasn't dissapointed!

Box/Instructions

Well the just the box of this set looks amazing :D and the instructions were easy to follow no problems at all 

Parts

Great parts such as a sandtrooper pauldron.
Sand colored pieces 

Minifigures

The highlight of every set in my opinion :D 
Its always great to have more stormtroopers also condsidering the fact they are quite rare with all these clone wars sets nowadays
Luke and Obi-wan have been totally redone and a welcome return
Another C3po Im fine with no problems there....
But yes yet another R2........Sheesh I have so many of them now....
All in all the minifigures in this set are well worth the price
PS.I have not included the other droid because to me it does not count as a figure...

The build

Easy and sort of nostalagic if you have built the previous 2 models :) 

The completed model

Superb! A great stunning remake of the landspeeder! I only wish somehow they could have put in the old engines for more of a classic old feel.
Only problem I have is that I wish at least they would include a dewback again or even part of the scenery for the sandtrooper(He looks so sad standing there alone :/)
The model is very playable and does not break easy 

Summary

A great superb remake to a classic set.Minifigures topnotch and excellent and the parts are definetely worth what you are paying. Thank You so much for reading this :D <3

author: AFOSL
title: Luke's (Third) Landspeeder
review:
In 1999 Lego released it's first wave of Star Wars kits.  Among them was the first model of Luke Skywalker's landspeeder.  This early model, although charming, was a very simple design and wasn't particularly accurate in terms of proportion and colour, being a little too short and stubby with a fairly vivid paint job.  This was typical of most Star Wars Lego sets at the time.
In 2004 the Landspeeder made another appearance.  This time it was included as part of a larger set (4501) that also contained a small building, a large animal mould (Dewback) and a good assortment of minifigures. The set was criticised for being too expensive, but it did contain some rare figures and the Landspeeder was very accurate in both shape and colour, using new colours such as sand red.
Does the new speeder follow the accurate design cues of the 2004 model or does it share more with it's early, 1999 iteration?

Box and Instructions

The Box for this model is surprisingly large when you consider that there is only one fairly small model contained within.
The front box art depicts the speeder whizzing into view on a suitably sandy backdrop with an Imperial Stormtrooper signalling the driver to slow down and stop.
The box front also shows all the minifigures in 1:1 scale that are contained inside. 
The rear of the box shows the speeder in a head on, slightly aerial view, showing the removable hatch of the speeder and the minifigures in poses that seem to imply that trouble is about to start.  Obi-Wan and Luke rushing to engage the Stormtrooper as C-3P0 flees the scene, whilst Artoo appears to have a leisurely chat with the Imperial sentry droid.
Other Star Wars models are advertised on the rear of the box - the rebel and Imperial Hoth battle packs and the Freeco speeder from the Clone Wars.  Very cold and icy kits when compared to the blistering twin suns of Tatooine where Luke's Landspeeder is found.

The instructions are printed in Lego's usual neat and presentable style.  The booklet contains 48 pages, including front and rear covers.  Why so many pages for such a small model?  Almost every page of the instruction manual contains only a single stage of construction, and even then many stages only require the builder to add one or two pieces to the model.  I'm sure the Model could be built in fewer stages and still be simple to construct.
The last few pages of the booklet are reserved for some Lego Club advertising and a few more models from the Star Wars line up in 2010.  There are also two pages of listed parts that are contained in the model, as well as a number for Customer Services, should you find any parts to be missing.

The Minifigures

In 2010 Lego redesigned the minifigure slightly, making further changes to the face.  In an attempt to add ever more detail to the figures, to appease demanding fans, Lego added a small white dot to each eye of their minifigures.  I can't really think why this was done, as it is not something that seems to have been asked for by the fans.  Maybe it is to add realism - a light reflection in each eye.  Or maybe it's to bring a typical minifigure a little closer to the cartoon style of the Clone wars figures.  Either way, it's a detail I have yet to get used to.  I find the white eye dots make my Luke and Ben look a little aggressive.
Apart from the white in the eyes, the Luke and Ben minifigures are almost the same as previous renditions.  Almost.  Both figures have more detail around the torso.  Ben appears to have more folds of cloth in his Jedi robes and he now wears a belt.  A cape and hood would have perfected the Obi-Wan minifigure for this set, and I still hope that one day we will see a cloaked and hooded Ben Kenobi in Lego form.
Luke also has slightly revised torso with a new design for his tunic as well as a much larger belt when compared to his 2004 speeder rendition.  Luke's trousers are also different.  His new trousers appear to have less detailing on them than in the past, although the detail more or less depict the same folds, creases and patterns.
Luke also sports new hair - the hair that most fans associate with female figures. I think this hair is quite suitable and represents the Skywalker mullet well.
Both figures come complete with blue lightsabers.

The two droids, C-3P0 and R2-D2 both feature in this kit. The Threepio minifigure hasn't changed much in recent years, being a deep gold colour with front and back torso printing and a nicely moulded head.
Artoo uses the new head head piece that was introduced in 2008.  His head is grey with full printing and is very accurate when compared to the pre 2008 rendition.  If there is one thing the Artoo figure needs, it's back printing.  If his dome can be printed all round, 360 degrees, why can't his body?

This kit contains only a single Imperial Stormtrooper.  Considering the cost of the set and the piece count, another Stormtrooper doesn't seem too much to ask for.  But there is only one.  What makes this one special when compared to nearly every other Stormtrooper, is his black shoulder pauldron.  It's made from the same material as the capes found on many other minifigures and it's just enough to make this Stormtrooper recognisable as Tatooine trooper on desert detail.  He looks even more the part when placed alongside the trooper from set 4501.  It's little touches like this that make collecting Star Wars Lego fun and interesting, as parts from one set can go towards making another look more complete as part of a scene from the movies they are based on.

The other figure in this kit is not really a figure at all.  It's a collection of elements, assembled to form a sentry droid.  Using some clear cylinder parts and some white cheese slopes, a small antenna and translucent red stud, the sentry droid is a small but neat construction and is the perfect companion for the Stormtrooper in this set.

The Landspeeder

The main part of this set is, of course, the speeder.  In answer to my earlier question concerning this speeders design aspects, the answer is clearly a mix of both speeder designs are incorporated into this model.  The speeder retains the shape of the 2004 model, but almost reverts back to the colour scheme from 1999.  The reason for the change of colour is simple.  Lego stopped producing sand red.  A crying shame in my opinion, as it was such an underused but authentic colour which added to the realism of many models and showed that Lego had an eye for fine detail.
Despite the abundance of tan on this speeder, the colour works.  It works now as it did in 1999.  It's obviously a colour that suits a speeder quite nicely, especially when placed alongside more accurate colours such as dark red and grey.
The build of the speeder closely resembles that of the model from 2004, with internal structure similarities, as well as the use of flexible plastic pipe for the detail towards the front of the craft.  Topside (hood) detail seems more 'involved', as if to say that there is something mechanical beneath the outer plating, but without comparison, the minimal surface detail means nothing.  It's really just detail for detail's sake.
Moving further back and you'll find one of the most interesting pieces - the curved windscreen.  This is much more authentic when compared to the 30 year old wedge design used on earlier models. 
The cockpit is placed quite far back on this model and contains seats for both passengers.  The drivers side also has a steering wheel.  With the cockpit so far back when compared to 2004's model, the nose becomes longer, whilst the rear end shrinks in length by a couple of studs.
The rear end of the model has probably had the biggest redesign when compared to the earlier models.  New parts are used for the engines which make them bigger and look more powerful.  Finally the speeder has turbine engines that look like turbines!  The damaged engine is still shown, using a smaller piece than the other two engines, with two discs attached to the front.  Showing damage at this scale with Lego elements isn't easy, but it's nice that Lego still represent damage where possible.  It can only add to the realism of a model.
The top engine is held in place with a Technic pin and sits on top of the rear storage compartment.  The storage compartment lid isn't hinged, but simply pulls away revealing a space big enough to hold Luke and Ben's Lightsabers.
Either side of the centre engine is enough space to securely seat both Artoo and Threepio.
The speeder glides on seven 2x2 inverted discs.  SEVEN!  I guess Lego had to figure a way to increase the piece count and justify the silly price tag.  The previous model managed with three discs, and I would say that four would be more than enough in any case.  But seven?  Once again, an extra minifigure would have cushioned the blow a bit better than unnecessary parts added to the underside of the speeder.

Final Thoughts

I like it.  It's grown on me.  I like that the original design has been kept and how it's been mostly improved upon with some new parts.  I think it's a shame that the sand red colour could not be used as I think that would be the icing on the cake for this rendition.  The tan suits it, but it's not movie accurate.
I'm not sure I'll ever get used to the new faces for Lego minifigures.  Face detail is normally a good thing, but the big eyes with the white highlight still looks a little odd to me.  Going from yellow to flesh tones was a major change, and an improvement.  I'm not sure why the eye change is necessary.
Like a lot of Star Wars Lego sets these days, the price to parts ratio is very poor and this model is over priced.  I'm not sure if this down to the world economy at the moment or if it's due to rising costs of licensing, if that has risen at all in recent years.  And to think, many people, including myself, once thought that the 2004 speeder, with it's cantina, it's Dewback, and  it's assortment of great minifigures, was expensive.  I'm sure we would all wish for those days again.  Things really weren't so bad, were they?

author: Nesquik
title: These 'are' the droids were looking for!
review:
Given how LEGO Star Wars products are so vastly over-priced, this was a rare purchase for myself as I normally resist giving in to the 'large box - nice pictures' syndrome when you're actually in a LEGO store. I can be forgiven this time however, as I've recently rekindled my love for the original films and wanted a product to satisfy some cravings before the Blu-rays are released! 

With an RRP of £25, this is without a doubt one of the worser value Star Wars sets. With only 163 bricks and a model that measures little more than 17x8cm, you can do yourself a favour and get this product from Amazon as they have severely undercut most other retailers. My only guess for the high RRP is because of the inclusion of 5 minifigures that, arguably, add up to one of the main reasons you'd by this set. Its widely known that minifigures bump up the prices of sets these days (hence why the City products include so few), but because this product is based on a scene of the film which includes all the relevant characters, it was a great choice on LEGO's part to include them all. An better price I believe would be £16, maximum.

The product is a vast improvement over the 1999 counterpart. Detail is fantastic throughout and the build was highly enjoyable because of this. I love the use of tubes in the front and how they were placed into the base, while the back section of the model - with the large engine in the centre - also reveals some storage space. The space is fairly small and sadly doesn't allow the lightsabers to fit in... So unless you want Luke and Obi Wan decapitating each other by accident, keep those 'sabers in-between the seating area! 

On the bottom of the Landspeeder you have a variety of concave flat-pieces that allows the product to 'glide' over carpets or smooth surfaces. This is a very nice touch that gives a realistic and fun attribute to how the vehicle should move. 

The mini-build is a tiny black and white droid that, if i'm correct, whizzed around in the air during the film, and it has a transparent stand to sit on which gives it a somewhat good illusion of floating in the air. Personally I don't think its the best addition since its not blindingly obvious what the build actually is, but its very small so no harm being included either. 

Our Stormtrooper has some great detailing with an over-the-shoulder cape that represents his ranking, a blaster gun and a contraption for his backpack. It never ceases to amaze me how much detail can be put into those helmets! 

I gladly recommend the product based purely on its authenticity and relevance to the original film itself. Its a well built, solid product that will please older fans for its detail and younger fans for its easy 'grasp' and lack of parts that are likely to fall off. As mentioned earlier, the only drawback is a lack of dedicated space for the lightsabers, so just improvise and use the cockpit/seating area.

author: Shistavanen_brick
title: "You'll have to sell your speeder..."
review:
Firstly, I do not own the 1999 version so I can't really compare with that. I will rather go with images in my memory-bank from watching Episode 4 instead. I remember when I sort of did an impulse buy with this set, remembering how big I thought the box was. That might be a warning sign for most future sets to come? 

I reckon, for the price point it would be a lot of going on with this set. Or even for the size of the box (though I got a reduced price), you sort of expect it to be grand. In a sense it really IS grand and cool but I feel it could do better with a couple of things. 

Landspeeder.

I like the colours with this one and it looks kind of similar to the "real deal" from EP4, although not quiiiiiite. The build was good and it has plenty of space for a driver and a co-pilot in the front. No real room to put the droids the stormtroopers "weren't" looking for, which is a bit of a downer, to be honest. Instead you can open the back to store lightsabers. Good thinking, though. The final result of the speeder - you have a very streamlined veichle. It looks quite small when it all comes down to it. There are no real features with the speeder - so maybe for some kind of sentimental value, it's worth getting (for AFOL people). Youngsters might want to have some more playability. 

Not too sure what would become of this set if it had fewer minifigures. It's not as exciting as the Freeco Speeder or the Sith Nightspeeder. However, this might be classed as a civilian veichle in the Galaxy far, far away.

Minifigures.

The box states that we get a total of 6 minifigures but I am not too keen on calling the Sentry droid a minifigure. If you decide to do that, it's perfectly ok. Others we get are: Luke Skywalker, Obi-Wan Kenobi, C3PO, R2D2 and a Stormtrooper. They are all great in their own way although, another R2....? It seems like this little astromech can find his way in at least one set a year. I like the Stormtrooper's outfit and small shoulder patch, looks nice. What this set would have needed is yet another Stormtrooper. When you think about the scene in EP4, there are more than one trooper (think it was 5) stopping Luke to check about the droids. So, instead of the sentry they should have included another trooper. More troopers are on the way under 2012, but THIS set lacks another.


Pros:
  • The design of the speeder sure looks nice, the colours and model leaves you satisfied, overall.
  • Quite a few minifigures when you come to think of it, compared to, let's say... the Freeco Speeder.
Cons:
  • Didn't come with another Stormtrooper.
  • Feels a bit tiny considering the box, price and on its own without minifigures.

author: orybloodmyre
title: Fun set, good playability, seriously overpriced though.
review:
I purchased this set today for 24.99 GBP.  It was either this or the Hoth Wampa cave set, but I decided to get this as I loved the original landspeeder set so much from back in 1999.

 

After constructing it, I certainly dont think it was worth the RRP. Its a nice set, but its too small a set to be charged 24.99 GBP. That equates as 40 USD. It isn't THAT much bigger than the original 1999 set, and I dont think packing loads of minifigures in really justifys the price. The sentry droid cant really be considred a minifigure, and I think it barely qualifies as a droid as it certainly looks like nothing I remember from a new hope!

 

This  set despite its flaws has some positives. I love the storage for the sabers in the back of the speeder, and I love how accurate it is to the speeder in a new hope what with the missing engine cover. It also bought back memories of putting my speeder together back in 1999 which was my first star wars lego set!

 

I wouldnt recommend this set nor would I condem it. It really is extortionate, but it has some nice mini-figures. It has a fair ammount of playability, but I would have liked some scenery or somthing for my money. A moisture vaporator would have done nicely!

 

In all this isnt an amazing set nor is it terrible. It will only go up in price after this year, so if you are after an accurate representation of the classic landspeeder from a new hope, and you think it is worth the price, go get it!

author: Mandalorian
title: Nice speeder with good minifigs.
review:
This set is very good for display. It looks nice and has a lot of great minifigures. The sandtrooper's Droid looks very good on some translucent pieces, almost like it's floating in the air. Both Luke and Ben have very nice faces and desert-like robes. C-3PO is a cool minifig, he looks quite a lot like in the movies. R2 is R2. The only things about this speeder that seem off to me are the engines and the cockpit. The latter is way too small and looks ridiculous with someone at the controls. The left engine is a failure in attempting to make it look broken. It looks too thin and different from the rest.
Pros:
  • Nice minifigures
  • Small, but sleek Landspeeder
  • Lots of small details on the speeder
  • Good price
  • A fair amount of nice parts.

Cons:

  • Cockpit is much too small and has a wrong shape
  • Left engine looks wierd
  • R2-D2 is too big.

Not being very expensive, I would reccomend getting this set. If you aren't fully satisfied with the speeder, you can use the good parts provided to build something different.

author: LEGOSLUG
title: The Big Review......
review:
Here is my review of the set 8092 Luke's Landspeeder. Overall this is a great set, read on.....


The Minifigures:

* Luke Skywalker--New Design Face with white pupils, and a new design Torso and legs.

* Obi-Wan Kenobi--Jedi robe torso, cream legs, whitepupils in his eyes, & a hair element.

* R2-D2--Grey dome, different body design.

* C-3PO--Yellow/Gold.

* Sand Trooper--Average Stormtrooper figure, only with a backpack.

* (Security Droid--Bricks).

The Build:

10 Mins build maximum, good structure, not weak in any way, setaing for the minifigures, Lightsaber storage, good size when completed, in proportion to the minifigures.


Now, on to the Pros and Cons.

Pros

 

* Lots of Minifigures, enough to recreate the movie scene.

* A more Realistic looking set, engine cover, colour, and so on.

* No Stickers.

* Storage for Lightsabers.

Cons

* R2-D2 has a light-gray blueish head, rather than the silver/white one.

* Expensive unless you buy it at sale price.

* Obi-wan doesn´t have a hood or cape!

 

All in all, it is a good set, brilliant for players and collectors of LEGO alike, If you are a Star Wars fan, buy it!

LEGOSLUG

P.S. Please see and rate my other reviews and bricklists :)

author: StratTone
title: Very cool perfectly done.
review: Wow what a set!  I love the way they did the wrap around for the front of the speeder!  Very affordable set that comes with awesome figures!  I hope this goes on sale so I can get another one.  :-)  The build was very fun and detailed.  End result???  Happy 33 year old closet star wars nerd.

author: dougts
title: Great Iconic Vehicle at an Entry Level Price
review:
Best Version yet of Luke's clunker.

Pros


  • 5 minifigures
  • hidden storage for light sabers (disassembled)
  • True to movie engine damage

Cons

  • a bit pricey - buy hey, it's a SW set, that's expected

This is a great lower-mid priced set for SW fans who want to get a good start on a minifig collections, or just have an iconic SW vehicle at a price point that won't break the bank. Everyone will instantly know what this is when they see it, unlike most of the current clone wars sets.

I got this for a desktop display on my desk at work - it's perfect.  Great conversation piece, and small enough to display without taking up a ton of space. The minifigs are instantly recognizable as well.

Speeder is solidly built, so it should play well for kids - you won't see parts flying off every time you hold it. All the minifigs should enhance play as well.

Yes, it's pricey for the piece count, but that's true with all the SW sets in general.  Considering you get 5 minifigures (at $3 each standard retail, you are essentially getting the speeder for $10), it's not that terrible however. Everyone wants more minifigs in sets, but then they complain about the price.  minifigs = $, so LEGO has a bit of a quandary on it's hands there.

author: mrmrstarwars101
title: Brilliant If You Like Collecting Figures
review:
Hello,

This is a great set if you love figures, it hasn't got a very large model but it is still worth it just for the figures!

Pros

  • This set has loads of awesome minifigures
  • It has very good play ability

Cons

  • The set isn't very large
  • It has a light-saber holder bet it can't fit the whole light-saber in

So if you are either a big colleter of figuers or you just wan't this set becuase the old one isn't for sale and rubish so you want the new one than this would be a great set for you!

author: Chills
title: Nice set, cool minifigures and features
review:
Luke's landspeeder is an iconic craft from the very first Star Wars movie ever released. Its a great example of how Lucas wanted items in his movies to look "used" and "gritty." This set does a good job of reflecting that feeling.

Pros

  • Pro 1: Like most of the recent sets LEGO designer(s) did a great job with keeping close to the craft used in the movie. The detail is quite authentic, including the "missing" engine cover on the left side, the driver's side on the right, side-by-side cockpit, and the small vane on the front.
  • Pro 2: Cool assortment of minifigures; a good addition to any collection.
  • Pro 3: The colors of the set are pretty neat, they are true to the movies. I like having Star Wars sets that are more than just different shades of grey (though I love those too.)
  • Pro 4: It has a couple of cool little features, like a spot in the back to put the lightsaber and a security droid. I also like the smooth circles on the bottom that allow the craft to "glide" across the floor.

Cons

  • Con 1: C-3PO is the old style, not the new one that is in the Droid Escape set. I would have liked to see the new one in this set, as well.
  • Con 2: As with the droid I would have liked to have the new Sandtrooper that is in Droid Escape in this set, too.

This is a great set on the inexpensive side. It was a fun build and a great addition to my collection.

author: zipsforbananas
title: I doubt this incarnation will be bettered.
review:
There have been a few dodgy landspeeders before, but this 2010 version is a real step up. It's all together more rounded, better coloured, better detailed - just better!

The landspeeder itself is really well designed, with a good core to the chassy and good detailing around. The pieces in the sides of the body add a really nice touch, and though it's very hard to get them in without catapulting the bracket pieces across the room, the long pieces you bend around the front are really great for the overall look. The engines at the back and the way they're attached is good, although I'm not sure why you get the corner pieces instead of 2x2 bricks and nothing to fill the hole. And the compartment for storing the lightsabers may not be movie accurate, but it's a very useful detail. One other niggle in terms of the build: I think adding the round 2x2 plates on the underside could have come earlier, as it does tend to fall apart quite easily as you're building it without them. And until you add a set of round 2x2 tiles to them it will look too close to the floor to really be hovering.

As good as the landspeeder is, it's the figures you get with it that are the real reason for the set! You get such a good set of key characters for such a cheap set. Obi-Wan is well printed, and no-one else will appreciate this but he looks so much like my Dad it's unreal! Luke needs better hair (we had to wait for 7965 for that), but his face, body and leg printing are really good. C-3PO and R2-D2 are far better than the older versions, particularly R2 with his grey, fully printed dome head. The 3PO in Droid Escape (9490) is better for the printed eyes and coloured circuits, but I think the overall feel is better with this one. The Sandtrooper is not at all up to the challenge of 9490's weathered version, but until they came out I was more than happy with him! I only wished his shoulder pad wasn't plain black. And though it's not actually a minifigure, the little droid is delightful, especially as it 'floats' on clear bricks!

Pros

  • Really good looking speeder - at last!
  • A great set of figures - five of them!

Cons

  • Pity it hovers so close to the floor, easily fixed though

A really great and affordable set that gives you a great set of really key characters that are quite hard to get in any other cheap sets. Well, well worth it for them alone, but the landspeeder itself is really great and good looking, and quite fun to build. Recommended!

author: Doctor_Bricks
title: Great Way to Move Around Tatooine!
review:
This set is a huge improvement on the original version. It is a very collectible item.

 

 

PROS:

1.Great minifigs; especially Old Ben Kenobi

2.Realistic details, like the gray flex tubes on the front

3.Sticks to the color scheme

 

CONS:

1.The sandtrooper has a black pauldron as opposed to an orange one

2.Only room for two minifigs instead of four

 

 

Overall, I give this set 4/5 stars. It is a great set for any LEGO Star Wars fan.

author: kubakwak123
title: Very good
review: I think this set is great. It includes C3PO and R2-D2, which are both minifigures I think are two of my favourites. Also, it includes Luke as well as the old Obi-Wan. It has a SandTrooper which is one of the rarer trooper figures. It also has a sentry droid which is a bit of a pointless character in my opinion... I think the Landspeeder is well designed. It looks better than the older versions, and also has a cool boot. I think all six characters and the landspeeder are worth their price. It is very good to play with and looks good as well!

author: DireStraits85
title: A must have for any Star Wars fan!
review: This set was my first Lego Star Wars set and was very important in the start of my collecting. The choice of minifigs in this set are great and make it easy to reenact the scenes from A New Hope. The build of the landspeeder is great and the set is perfect for display or play. This set is great for the price and is a great set for any Star Wars collector or fan!

author: alfred_the_buttler
title: Very fun little set!
review:
I just picked up this set dirt cheap for $6 minus the minifigures. Ever since the XP -38 came out, they just aren't in demand! I highly recommend that if you can find it cheap that you take advantage of it, it is well worth the price I paid. 

Now that said, there is nothing amazing about this set, no revolutionary building techniques, no moving parts, and aside from the engines, no special must have bricks. Of course the real value of this set was in the minifigures which I didn’t get, but I already have all of them except for the little droid which I parted together on Bricklink for a few cents. But what makes this set great is that it gives you the vehicle that started the whole Star Wars saga. And while the landspeeder may not have lasted for all that long in the movies, this small little set is appropriately sized and priced for an iconic vehicle like this. 

As for the design, this Lego set is instantly recognizable as Luke’s landspeeder. While it may not be as sleek as the vehicle in the movies, Lego did a great job designing it with the 90 degree angles that they have to work with. Plus the use of two rigid hoses to represent the grill looks brilliant. The only shortfall of this set is that while it has seats for Luke and Obiwan, it lacks seats for the droids. Both of them can kind of just be placed on the back, but they don’t have actual seats. Of course I don’t blame Lego, it would be very difficult to fit in R2 given how wide his minifigure is. 

Overall this is a great set for playing with. The top engine can be removed so you can access a trunk, but that is the only “play feature”. It’s just a great set to drive/fly around. Perfect for little kids, and they can build it easily as well.

author: Slobrojoe
title: An unbeaten classic
review:
Lego has made a considerable amount of Luke's Landspeeders in the past, 6 of which have been (debatably) minifigure scale. 21 years have passed since the original model, meaning that we get 1 every 3.5 years on average which is probably a bit over the top. Today, I am looking at 8092 Luke's Landspeeder, which was released in 2010. I have some fond memories of it when I received it for my birthday around 2013, and might be the only set you could say I have 'nostalgia' for, seeing as I wasn't around for the Classic themes like Space, Castle and Pirates. 
 

Parts

The set includes 163 pieces, making it the second largest of the 4 standalone speeders. Despite this, the pieces are all pretty common, with the rarest piece being the Sandtrooper's pauldron, which isn't even plastic. Nothing to see here... move along, move along...

 

Minifigures 

5 or 6 minifigures are included in this set, depending on your opinion about what classes as one. 
 

Obi-Wan Kenobi: exclusive to this set, Obi-Wan has his classic smooth grey hair that is found in Obi-Wan's hut and a lot of the newish sets. He features an appropriate head piece printed with wrinkles and facial hair seen in the movies. Having to adapt to Tatooine, Kenobi wears sand robes with a brown top underneath to keep the Jedi tradition. Plain sand legs are provided.

Luke Skywalker: exclusive to this set, Luke has long blonde hair in accordance with A New Hope. The facial expression is a pretty plain smile. Luke works on his Uncle Owen Lars' moisture farm, extracting water vapour from the air. He wears simple white robes with a brown utility belt. Luke also has leg printing, which is pretty good for 2010, that finishes off his white robes and ends in tan trousers\pants. 
 

R2-D2: a pretty standard variant with blue printing on the grey dome and tools printed on the front of the body.

C3-P0: also a pretty standard variant with mediocre printing on the torso and a pearl gold colour.

Imperial Sandtrooper: exclusive to this set. Sandtroopers can be found on planets with sandy or extreme terrain. In this instance, he is one of the security troopers posted in Mos Eisley to find the two stowaway droids who are carrying the Death Star plans. He matches the on-screen character perfectly with a survival pack, making good use of two light grey lightsaber hilts. He has a black pauldron to signify his rank and division. The helmet is perfect, with blue grills on the side and nice shadowing. The head underneath is black and the torso has the standard Stormtrooper utility belt printing and plain white legs.

Sentry Droid: exclusive to this set and is a perfect addition to the set. Comprised of 8 basic pieces, it is made to look like it is floating as shown in the Star Wars universe. 
 

Build

The build is pretty simple and not very repetitive. It took me exactly 14 minutes and 29 seconds to build casually, including rummaging around for a couple of missing tiles. 
 

The Completed Model

The speeder looks excellent in tan/sand with maroon tile highlights, despite appearing in sand red on-screen. I love how the engines are mismatched and there are some grills dotted around to give it that well-worn feel. Luke and Obi-Wan can sit snugly in the speeder, whilst Threepio chills out at the back near the engine like in the film. You can remove the panel attached to the dorsal engine to reveal a small space to hide lightsabers, blasters or illegal contraband (this being Mos Eisley and all). There isn't much play value besides the storage, but the side engines can be removed pretty easily if a crash or shoot-out occurred. The grill at the front is represented by two long tubes curled around the front and kept in place by three ledges, which looks really good aesthetically but can cause some difficulty in putting it back in place if dropped or damaged.

Overall Opinion

I think that the colour scheme, despite a little inaccurate, works extremely well in this set and the 4 unique minifigures only compliment that more. For a £25 or $25 set, it is a little overpriced in the respect of the piece count, but some of that cost will definitely be because of the exclusive minifigures. If you manage to find it for around retail price now, I definitely suggest that you pick it up because it can only improve your LEGO Star Wars collection and, you never know, might put your other Luke's Landspeeders to shame.
